text: Orobanche hederae, the ivy broomrape, is, like other members of the genus Orobanche, a parasitic plant without chlorophyll, and thus totally dependent on its host, which is ivy. It grows to , with stems in shades of brown and purple, sometimes yellow. The flowers are long, cream in colour with reddish- purple veins. ==Etymology== Orobanche is derived from Greek, and means 'legume strangler'. This name originates from the species Orobanche rapum-genistae, which parasitizes legumes. The name hederae means 'of ivy', in reference to its host plant, Hedera.Gledhill, David (2008). "The Names of Plants". Cambridge University Press. (hardback), (paperback). pp 193, 284 ==References== hederae
title: Orobanche hederae
